sections.title: Landlord Entry Requirements
sections.text: Landlords must provide at least 24 hours written notice before entering a rental unit, except in cases of emergency. The notice must specify the date, approximate time, and purpose of entry. Entry without proper notice violates California Civil Code.

sections.title: Security Deposit Limits and Refundability
sections.text: In California, security deposits are limited to 2 months' rent for unfurnished units and 3 months' rent for furnished units. All deposits must be refundable and returned within 21 days of lease termination with itemized deductions. Landlords cannot make deposits 'non-refundable' or exercise unilateral discretion over returns.

sections.title: Lease Renewal Requirements
sections.text: Leases cannot automatically renew without explicit tenant consent. Tenants must receive written notice at least 30 days before lease expiration if the landlord wishes to renew or change terms. Automatic renewal clauses may be unenforceable.

sections.title: Warranty of Habitability
sections.text: Landlords must maintain rental units in habitable condition, including working heat, plumbing, electricity, and compliance with all housing codes. Tenants may withhold rent or 'repair and deduct' if landlords fail to make necessary repairs. Landlords cannot shift repair responsibilities to tenants for essential systems.

sections.title: Protection Against Retaliatory Eviction
sections.text: Landlords cannot evict tenants in retaliation for exercising their rights, such as filing complaints about housing code violations, joining tenant organizations, requesting repairs, or organizing with other tenants. Retaliatory evictions are illegal under California law.
